--- title: Lesson 12 - Natural Language Processing II keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar summary: "Analyse text with machine learning - part 2." ---

{% include image.html file="/dslectures/./images/sentiment-meme.jpg" %}

In the last lecture we looked at two ways to encode text documents as vectors, namely

  • Count encodings
  • TF-IDF encodings

Once text documents are encoded in numerical vectors we can apply all the classifiers and regressors we already know from scikit.

In addition to these two these encodings we have look at two new methods in this notebook:

  • n-grams
  • Word embeddings

While n-grams help model sequential dependencies (like the order) or elements in the text, the word embeddings are vectors for words that themselves already carry semantic meaning.

Also, we have a look at a new classifier called a Naive Bayes classifier which is a powerful classifier for large corpora.

To showcase how these methods compare we apply them to the IMDB dataset which consists of movie reviews. This is a sentiment analysis benchmark with each text having a label whether it is a postive or negative review.

In the last section of the notebook we investigate the sample efficiency of each method. In other words we explore which of the approaches need a lot of data to work well and which ones work already with very data samples.

Created by: Leandro von Werra, Spring 2019

IMDB Dataset¶

First, we load the IMDB dataset as a dataframe. Note that this is not the original dataset from here, but a version that I pre-processed for the ease of use.

The dataset consists of a filename, text, sentiment and a train_label. The latter splits the data into a train and test set which is used as the official benchmark. We will follow that same split.

Before that, let's have a look at a few text examples:

def print_n_samples(df, n):
    """
    Helper function to plot data samples from IMDB dataset.
    """
    for i in range(n):
        print('SAMPLE', i+1, '\n')
        df_sample = df.sample(1)
        print(df_sample['text'].values[0])
        print('\nSentiment:', df_sample['sentiment'].values[0],'\n')
        print("".join(100*['=']))

print_n_samples(df_imdb, 2)

SAMPLE 1 

Jörg Buttgereit goes a bit too far with his movies and themes at times, even for my taste but his movies are always something special and hard to classify. They are artistically made, with also often deeper meaning to its themes. This movie is a perfect example of his work.<br /><br />It's also really hard to label this movie. It's not really a movie with a story to it, in a sense of having a beginning, middle and end in it. It also doesn't have a main character but instead focuses on 7 different suicides and killings, on 7 different days.<br /><br />All different stories are being told with lots of class, though some of them are of course more 'interesting' and realistic than the others. They are not necessarily connected but yet together they still tell a story. The movie doesn't feel disjointed at all. All different stories have a different feel to it and Buttgereit tells the story without hardly using any words (also typical for his style) but instead lets the images and obvious sensible emotions of the characters tell the entire story. It helps to make this movie an effective one to watch.<br /><br />Again, the production values all aren't too high and this might be something that might scare off some people. It however helps for this particular movie to set the right tone and atmosphere for the entire movie and its dark, disturbing and depressing themes.<br /><br />A Buttgereit movie that I 'enjoyed' watching.<br /><br />7/10

SAMPLE 2 

Roman Polanski is considered as one of the most important directors of our time, as the mind behind classics such as "Rosemary's Baby" and "Chinatown". Probably what makes Polanski's cinema a very interesting one is the fact that while he is capable of creating commercially attractive films such as the afore mentioned masterpieces, he is also fond of making low-key movies that are of a more personal nature. "Le Locataire", or "The Tenant", is one of those movies; a horror/suspense story about paranoia and obsession that is among his best works and probably among the best horror movies ever done.<br /><br />Polanski himself plays Telkovsky, a young man looking for an apartment in France. When he finally finds one, he discovers that it is empty because the previous tenant, Simone Choule, attempted to kill herself by jumping out of the window. After Simone dies of the injuries, Trelkovsky begins to become obsessed with her, to the point of believing that her death was caused by the rest of the tenants in the building.<br /><br />While sharing the same claustrophobic feeling of his other "apartment-themed" films ("Repulsion & "Rosemary's Baby"); this film focuses on the bizarre conspiracy that may or may not be entirely in Trelkovsky's head, the catastrophic effects the paranoia has on his mind, and the bizarre obsession he has with the previous tenant.<br /><br />Trelkovsky's descend into darkness is portrayed perfectly by Polanski. While at first his performance seems odd and wooden, slowly one finds out that Polanski acts that way because Trelkovsky is meant to be acted that way; as a simpleton with almost no life, who traps himself in this maddening sub-world that happens to be inhabited by a collection of bizarre people. The supporting actors really gave life to the people in the building creating memorable characters that are very important for the success of the film.<br /><br />Also, the beautiful cinematography Polanski employs in the film helps to increase the feeling of isolation, and gives life to the beautiful building that serves as cage for Trelkovsky. The haunting images Polanski uses to convey the feeling of confusion and madness are of a supernatural beauty that makes them both frightening and attractive.<br /><br />If a flaw is to be found in the film, is that it is definitely a bit slow at first. this may sound like a turn-off but in fact the slow pace of the beginning works perfectly as it mimics Trelkovsky's own boring life and how gradually he enters a different realm. Also, the convoluted storyline is definitely not an easy one to understand due to the many complex layers it has. However, more than a flaw, it is a joy to face a thought-provoking plot like this one.<br /><br />While "The Tenant" may not be for everyone, those interested in psychological horror and surreal story lines will be pleased by the experience. "Le Locataire" is really one of Roman Polanksi's masterpieces. 10/10

We salavge the pre-processing function from last lesson:

def preprocessing(text, language='english', stemming=True):
    """
    preprocess a string and return processed tokens.
    args:
        text: text string
    return:
        tokens: list of processed and cleaned words
    """
    
    stop_words = set(stopwords.words(language))
    stemmer = SnowballStemmer(language)    
    
    text = text.lower()
    tokens = word_tokenize(text)
    tokens = [i for i in tokens if not i in stop_words]
    tokens = [i for i in tokens if i.isalpha()]
    if stemming:
        tokens = [stemmer.stem(i) for i in tokens]
    
    return tokens

Now, we apply it this function to all texts in the DataFrame:

df_imdb['text_processed_stemmed'] = df_imdb['text'].progress_apply(preprocessing)

progress: 100%|██████████| 50000/50000 [03:05<00:00, 269.28it/s]

For the word embeddings we won't need stemmed words, since there exist word vectors for each variation of the word. This is why we run the processing a second time with the option stemming=False.

df_imdb['text_processed_unstemmed'] = df_imdb['text'].progress_apply(preprocessing, **{'stemming': False})

progress: 100%|██████████| 50000/50000 [01:35<00:00, 523.55it/s]

Now, we can use the split function to separate the dataset into train and test:

df_imdb_train, df_imdb_test = split_train_test_df(df_imdb)

Sentiment Analysis¶

This is a helper function that gives us the right vectorizer with the settings we need in one line:

def get_vectorizer(vec_type, vobab_size, ngram_range):
    
    def identity(doc):
        return doc
    
    if vec_type == 'count':
        tfidf_vec = TfidfVectorizer(analyzer='word',
                            tokenizer=identity,
                            preprocessor=identity,
                            token_pattern=None,
                            max_features=vocab_size,
                            ngram_range=ngram_range)
        return tfidf_vec
    elif vec_type == 'tf-idf':
        count_vec = CountVectorizer(analyzer='word',
                            tokenizer=identity,
                            preprocessor=identity,
                            token_pattern=None,
                            max_features=vocab_size,
                            ngram_range=ngram_range)
        return count_vec
    
    else:
        raise NameError('No vectorizer called "' + str(vec_type) + '".')

We also setup a function to that fits the training data to a classifier and returns the accuracy:

def fit_classifier(clf, x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test):
    clf.fit(X_train, y_train)
    y_pred = clf.predict(X_test)
    return 100*accuracy_score(y_pred, y_test)

Count encodings, unigram¶

Training data¶

With the helper function we now create a count vectorizers:

vocab_size = 100000
ngram_range = [1,1]

tfidf_vec = get_vectorizer('tf-idf', vocab_size, ngram_range)
count_vec = get_vectorizer('count', vocab_size, ngram_range)

Now we fit the training data to the vectorizer and transform the texts to vectors.

X_train = count_vec.fit_transform(df_imdb_train['text_processed_stemmed'])
X_test = count_vec.transform(df_imdb_test['text_processed_stemmed'])

y_train = df_imdb_train['sentiment']
y_test = df_imdb_test['sentiment']

X_train.shape, X_test.shape

((25000, 47730), (25000, 47730))

Finally, we fit three classifier to the unigram count encodings. Since the classes are well balanced it is ok in this case to just look at the accuracy.

Random Forest¶

rnd_clf = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100)
acc = fit_classifier(rnd_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 84.55%

Naive Bayes¶

mnb_clf = MultinomialNB()
acc = fit_classifier(mnb_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 82.15%

Logistic Regression¶

lr_clf = LogisticRegression(solver='lbfgs')
acc = fit_classifier(lr_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 87.59%

Count encodings, 5-gram¶

Now we do the same procedure but use up to 5 grams in the vectorizer.

Training Data¶

vocab_size = 1000000
ngram_range = [1,5]

count_vec = get_vectorizer('count', vocab_size, ngram_range)

X_train = count_vec.fit_transform(df_imdb_train['text_processed_stemmed'])
X_test = count_vec.transform(df_imdb_test['text_processed_stemmed'])

Random Forest¶

rnd_clf = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100)
acc = fit_classifier(rnd_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 84.96%

Naive Bayes¶

mnb_clf = MultinomialNB()
acc = fit_classifier(mnb_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 86.04%

Logistic Regression¶

lr_clf = LogisticRegression(solver='lbfgs')
acc = fit_classifier(lr_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 87.80%

TF-IDF encodings, 5-grams¶

Word embeddings¶

The last method we investigate is using word embeddings as features. There are many pre-trained word vectors available trained on various datasets (see here). We use word emebeddings trained on the Google news dataset. The dataset we provided is prefiltered to only include words from the IMDB dataset.

Note: If you want to experiment with word embeddings yourself have a look at the gensim library.

First, we load the filtered word embeddings. To do this we use the pickle package which allows to quickly store python objects and load them in another session. With this module you can for example also store trained scikit models and later just load them to make predictions.

get_dataset('embeddings')

with open('../data/word2vec-google-news-300.pkl', 'rb') as f:
    word_vec = pickle.load(f)

The word_vec object is a dictionary that returns the vector for strings:

Note that not all possible words are in the dictionary and you get errors you look for a word that is not in the dictionary:

word_vec['qwert']

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

We can check if a key exists in a dictionary:

'qwert' in word_vec

False

Semantic arithmetic¶

One reason word embeddings caused a lot of excitment in the community when they were introduced was their arithmetic properties. This means that one can find words by adding and subtracting words:

girl_vec = word_vec['women'] + (word_vec['boy'] - word_vec['men'] )

The similarity between the constructed word vector and the actual vector for "girl" is higher than than between any of the vectors we used to construct the word vector:

cosine_similarity([girl_vec], [word_vec['girl']])[0][0]

0.8533967
cosine_similarity([girl_vec], [word_vec['men']])[0][0]

0.18732116
cosine_similarity([girl_vec], [word_vec['boy']])[0][0]

0.82831436
cosine_similarity([girl_vec], [word_vec['women']])[0][0]

0.40730804

Next we create a function that takes a list of tokens as input and creates a vector for the whole list:

def vectorize_sentence_with_word_embeddings(tokens, word_emb_dict, normalize=True):
    """
    Create sentence embeddings from tokens with a dictionary containing word embeddings.
    args:
        tokens: list of strings
        word_emb_dict: dictionary with word embeddings
        
    returns:
        1-d numpy array with sentence embedding
    """
    
    # get dimensions of word vectors 
    dim = 300#len(list(word_emb_dict.values())[0])
    
    # initialize empty word vector
    vec = np.zeros(dim)
    
    # create a counter for embedded words in case the vector is normalized
    emb_count = 0
    
    # for each word in the list of tokens, check if it is in the dictionary
    # and if yes, add the word embedding to vec and increase counter
    for word in tokens:
        if word in word_emb_dict:
            emb_count += 1
            vec += word_emb_dict[word]
    
    # if normalization flag is set, normalize the vector by the number
    # encoded words
    if normalize:
        vec /= emb_count
    
    return vec

If we apply this to a test sentence we see that we get a vector of dimension 300:

vec = vectorize_sentence_with_word_embeddings(['this', 'is', 'a', 'test'], word_vec)

len(vec)

300
print(vec)

Now we have to split the dataset again, since we added a new column witht the text embeddings:

df_imdb_train, df_imdb_test = split_train_test_df(df_imdb)

To get them into matrix form required for X, we can stack than on top of each other with np.vstack.

X_train = np.vstack(df_imdb_train['text_embeddings'].values)
X_test = np.vstack(df_imdb_test['text_embeddings'].values)

lr_clf = LogisticRegression(solver='lbfgs')
acc = fit_classifier(lr_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 85.18%

rnd_clf = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100)
acc = fit_classifier(rnd_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test)
print('Accuracy: %.2f%%' % (acc))

Accuracy: 80.34%

Sample Efficiency¶

As a last thing we want to investigate how efficient these approaches are in terms of samples. In many real world applications the number of labelled samples is very limited and is very useful to know which approaches work best in different scenarios. This is the goal of this section. In particular we look at the following things:

  • unigram vs. 5 gram
  • count encodings vs. word embeddings
  • Logistic regression vs. Naive Bayes classifier

First we setup the count vectorizer and define a list of sample sizes we want to investigate:

count_vec_uni = get_vectorizer('count', 100000, [1,1])
count_vec_5 = get_vectorizer('count', 1000000, [1,5])

count_vec_uni.fit(df_imdb_train['text_processed_stemmed'])
count_vec_5.fit(df_imdb_train['text_processed_stemmed'])
sample_sizes = [8, 40, 200, 1000, 5000, 25000]

For each approach we create an empty list to store the results of each experiment. Then we iterate through each sample size and measure the accuracy of each apprach and store them in the lists.

acc_rnd_uni = []
acc_nb_uni = []
acc_lr_uni = []

acc_nb_5 = []
acc_lr_5 = []

acc_we_lr = []
acc_we_rf = []

for n in tqdm(sample_sizes):
    
    df_imdb_train, df_imdb_test = split_train_test_df(df_imdb)
    
    # sub sample the training data:
    df_imdb_train = df_imdb_train.sample(n)
    
    y_train = df_imdb_train['sentiment']
    y_test = df_imdb_test['sentiment']
    
    # Unigrams
    X_train = count_vec_uni.transform(df_imdb_train['text_processed_stemmed'])
    X_test = count_vec_uni.transform(df_imdb_test['text_processed_stemmed'])

    lr_clf = LogisticRegression(solver='lbfgs')
    acc_lr_uni.append(fit_classifier(lr_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test))
    
    mnb_clf = MultinomialNB()
    acc_nb_uni.append(fit_classifier(mnb_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test))
    
    # 5-gram
    X_train = count_vec_5.transform(df_imdb_train['text_processed_stemmed'])
    X_test = count_vec_5.transform(df_imdb_test['text_processed_stemmed'])

    lr_clf = LogisticRegression(solver='lbfgs')
    acc_lr_5.append(fit_classifier(lr_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test))
    
    mnb_clf = MultinomialNB()
    acc_nb_5.append(fit_classifier(mnb_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test))
    
    
    # Word Embeddings
    X_train = np.vstack(df_imdb_train['text_embeddings'].values)
    X_test = np.vstack(df_imdb_test['text_embeddings'].values)
    
    lr_clf = LogisticRegression(solver='lbfgs')
    acc_we_lr.append(fit_classifier(lr_clf, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test))

100%|██████████| 6/6 [02:05<00:00, 24.42s/it]

plt.figure(figsize=(16, 8))

sns.lineplot(sample_sizes, acc_lr_uni, label='Logistic Regression (unigram)')
sns.lineplot(sample_sizes, acc_nb_uni, label='Naive Bayes (unigram)')
sns.lineplot(sample_sizes, acc_lr_5, label='Logistic Regression (5-gram)')
sns.lineplot(sample_sizes, acc_nb_5, label='Naive Bayes (5-gram)')
sns.lineplot(sample_sizes, acc_we_lr, label='Logistic Regression (embeddings)')

plt.grid(True)
plt.xscale('log')
plt.ylabel('Accuracy')
plt.xlabel('Training Samples')

Text(0.5, 0, 'Training Samples')

Exercise 3: Interpret the results of the experiment. Which approaches work best in the different regimes (from very few samples to large datasets)?

Samples from the word embedding classifier¶

Let's have a look at the at a few samples and see how the classifier performs!

i = np.random.randint(0, len(df_imdb))

print(df_imdb.loc[i, 'text'])
print()
print('prediction:', lr_clf.predict([df_imdb.loc[i, 'text_embeddings']])[0])
print('true label:', df_imdb.loc[i, 'sentiment'])

I hoped to learn something from this movie, but I was disappointed. It is all about Rommel and lauds him as a great general, but at no time in this entire movie did we ever get an idea of why he was great. What made him so successful? Was it his drive, his unwillingness to accept defeat, his discipline with his men? I was looking for a Patton-like rendition that really gets into the character, but this fell way flat. Most of the dialog is contrived and sensationalized, and feels stale and artificial. There is some good action here and there, but not much. The tail end of the story, which discusses his involvement in the plot to assassinate Hitler, was the most informative part and probably the most interesting. But as a history lesson on Germany's greatest general, this was a failure.

prediction: neg
true label: neg
